Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Improving Model Parameterization of Energetic Fluxes in the Boundary Layer over Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
A joint NSF and DOE Atmospheric Radiation Measurement (ARM) West Antarctic Radiation Experiment (AWARE, PLR-1443549), is currently collecting a wide range of meteorological, radiation, and cloud microphysical data from McMurdo, Ross Island and also in part at the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide field camp. These observational efforts will serve to better characterize Antarctic climate.

This RAPID award will additionally allow a US PI to participate in the French field program at Dome C entitled "Improving Model Parameterization of Energetic Fluxes in the Boundary Layer over Antarctica - CALVA." In addition to planned collaboration between the PI with her French colleagues from Laboratoire de Geophysique et Geophysique de l'Environnement (LGGE), there is expected to be a collaboration with the science teams for the joint AWARE and CALVA efforts.

One AWARE objective is to observe the impact of long-range moisture transport from Southern Ocean storm tracks on cloud formation and microphysics, and ultimately to better understand the surface radiation and energy budget over Antarctic regions vulnerable to ice mass loss. Comparing AWARE measurement sets to the high terrain of East Antarctica, at Dome C, will allow conclusions as to the ice mass balance to be reached throughout the larger continental area. It is for this concurrency of data intensive measurement campaigns that a RAPID award is desirable and appropriate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Dana Veron traveled by boat and plane to Concordia Station, located at Dome C, as part of the “RAPID: Improving Model Parameterization of Energetic Fluxes in the Boundary Layer over Antarctica” project.  While at Dome C, Dr. Veron worked with French colleague Dr. Christophe Genthon from the University of Grenoble and the CALVA (Calibration – validation of meteorological and climate models and satellite retrieval, Antarctic coast to Dome C) project installing and performing maintenance on meteorological instruments that were installed on a 2-m tall and a 45-m tower.  These instruments collect critical information on atmospheric temperature, humidity, and pressure as well as wind speed and direction at several heights between the surface and the top of the 45-m tower.  These data form the basis for a unique characterization of the extreme conditions at Dome C, can be used to ground-truth available satellite data and provide necessary information to force and/or evaluate weather forecasting and climate models. 

 

In particular, the data from this project are being used as part of a GEWEX Atmospheric Boundary Layer model intercomparison study, GABLS4 (http://www.umr-cnrm.fr/aladin/meshtml/GABLS4/GABLS4.html ), that is focusing on improving our understanding, and ability to model, the very bottom of the atmosphere.  This is particularly important at Dome C where, when the atmosphere is very calm, we see very large changes in heat and moisture fluxes over small vertical distances (~40m).  For models, these big jumps in physical and energetic features over small distances are difficult to capture.  However, improvement of our ability to model the stable boundary layer will lead to better forecasting of local meteorological conditions, which is critical in assisting flight and base operations at the scientific stations at Dome C and along the coast downwind such as McMurdo Station.  It will also improve understanding of the extreme climate on the Eastern Antarctic Plateau.
